skill.name: GeoPandas
skill.description: Python library for working with geospatial vector data including shapefiles, GeoJSON, and GeoPackage files. Use when working with geographic data for spatial analysis, geometric operations, coordinate transformations, spatial joins, overlay operations, choropleth mapping, or any task involving reading/writing/analyzing vector geographic data. Supports PostGIS databases, interactive maps, and integration with matplotlib/folium/cartopy. Use for tasks like buffer analysis, spatial joins between datasets, dissolving boundaries, clipping data, calculating areas/distances, reprojecting coordinate systems, creating maps, or converting between spatial file formats.
skill.summary: Process and analyze geospatial vector data with Python
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing markdown files with Python code examples. All 193 static analyzer findings are false positives: the analyzer misinterpreted Python API calls (like gdf.to_crs) as shell commands, EPSG geospatial codes as cryptographic algorithms, and attribute access operations as system reconnaissance. No executable code or security risks present.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at SKILL.md:15-244 (27 occurrences)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: These are Python code examples in markdown documentation, not shell backticks. Examples include 'uv pip install geopandas', 'gdf.to_crs(EPSG:3857)', and 'gdf.geometry.buffer(10)'. All are legitimate GeoPandas API calls shown as documentation examples.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at SKILL.md:3
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: The analyzer flagged 'EPSG:4326' as a weak cryptographic algorithm. EPSG codes are Coordinate Reference System identifiers used in geospatial work, not cryptographic algorithms. EPSG:4326 is WGS84 geographic coordinate system.
Lines like 'print(gdf.crs)' and 'gdf.geometry.bounds' are attribute access operations for geospatial data inspection. These are standard GeoPandas operations, not system reconnaissance commands.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/crs-management.md (36 occurrences)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Python code examples showing CRS operations: 'gdf.to_crs(EPSG:3857)', 'gdf.crs.to_epsg()', 'transformer.transform(x, y)'. Documentation examples only, no shell commands.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at references/crs-management.md:71
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: WKT2 (Well-Known Text) format for CRS definitions flagged as weak crypto. WKT is a geospatial standard for describing coordinate reference systems, not a cryptographic format.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/data-io.md (25 occurrences)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Python I/O examples: 'gpd.read_file(data.geojson)', 'gdf.to_parquet(data.parquet)'. Documentation showing file operations, not shell commands.
Example URLs like 'https://example.com/data.geojson' are standard documentation examples. No real network calls or credential exfiltration.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/data-structures.md (7 occurrences)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Python data structure examples: 'gpd.GeoSeries([Point(1, 1)])', 'gpd.GeoDataFrame(df)'. Documentation examples, not commands.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/geometric-operations.md (39 occurrences)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Python geometric operations: 'gdf.geometry.buffer(10)', 'gdf.geometry.simplify(tolerance=5)'. Standard Shapely integration examples.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at references/geometric-operations.md:3
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Shapely library reference flagged as crypto. Shapely is a geometric manipulation library, not cryptographic software.
Attribute access like 'gdf.geometry.centroid', 'gdf.geometry.bounds' are geometric property accessors, not system reconnaissance.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/spatial-analysis.md (22 occurrences)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Python spatial analysis examples: 'gpd.sjoin(gdf1, gdf2)', 'gpd.overlay(gdf1, gdf2)'. Documentation for spatial operations.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at references/spatial-analysis.md:88
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Overlay operation with 'how=intersection' flagged. This is a set-theoretic geometric operation, not cryptography.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/visualization.md (30 occurrences)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Python visualization examples: 'gdf.plot(column=population)', 'gdf.explore()'. Matplotlib integration examples.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at references/visualization.md:3
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: matplotlib integration reference flagged. This is a plotting library, not cryptographic software.

content.value_statement: GeoPandas extends pandas for geospatial operations. It enables reading shapefiles, GeoJSON, and PostGIS data; performing spatial joins, buffer analysis, and coordinate transformations; and creating choropleth maps with matplotlib integration.
actual_capabilities: Read and write spatial data in Shapefile, GeoJSON, GeoPackage, and Parquet formats
Perform spatial joins, overlays, and dissolve operations on vector geometries
Transform coordinates between CRS (EPSG codes, WKT, PROJ strings)
Create buffer, simplify, centroid, and affine transformations on geometries
Generate choropleth maps and interactive maps with folium integration
Query PostGIS databases and cloud storage (S3, Azure, HTTP)
limitations: Only handles vector data (points, lines, polygons), not raster or grid data
Does not include geocoding, routing, or network analysis capabilities
Requires additional packages for interactive maps (folium) or advanced projections (cartopy)

use_cases.title: Spatial Data Analysis
use_cases.description: Analyze geographic patterns in datasets by joining spatial features, calculating areas, and identifying intersections.

use_cases.title: Urban Development Mapping
use_cases.description: Load shapefiles, clip to study areas, dissolve boundaries, and create publication-ready choropleth maps.

use_cases.title: Environmental Impact Studies
use_cases.description: Combine multiple spatial datasets, perform overlay analysis, and track changes over time with coordinate transformations.

prompt_templates.title: Load and explore data
prompt_templates.prompt: Read a shapefile and show its CRS, geometry types, and basic statistics

prompt_templates.title: Perform spatial join
prompt_templates.prompt: Join point locations to polygon boundaries using a spatial join with the intersects predicate

prompt_templates.title: Create buffer analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 500-meter buffer around all features and calculate the total buffered area

prompt_templates.title: Build interactive map
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an interactive folium map with a choropleth layer colored by population values

output_examples.input: Read my shapefile and show basic info

best_practices: Always check CRS before spatial operations and reproject to a projected CRS for accurate area and distance measurements
Use spatial indexes and bbox filtering during file reads to improve performance with large datasets
Validate geometries with .is_valid before complex operations and repair invalid features using .buffer(0)
anti_patterns: Do not calculate areas or distances using geographic CRS (EPSG:4326) - results will be meaningless in degrees
Do not ignore geometry validity - invalid polygons can cause unexpected results in spatial joins
Do not use Shapefile format for production data - it has 2GB file size limit and poor datetime support

faq.question: What formats can GeoPandas read?
faq.answer: GeoPandas reads Shapefile, GeoJSON, GeoPackage, KML, Parquet, Feather, and PostGIS via SQL queries. Cloud storage via fsspec is also supported.
